The issue is that the snapshots need to be complete because they're testing added features and other changes.  Having them broad makes it easier to catch problems too, so it's in nobody's interest to keep them limited.  Even if they were limited, it would still be public information.  You can bet that the YouTubers who currently put out snapshot videos would make sure that they are in the testing group and still make those videos.

Anyone who wants the next update to be a surprise can decide to not read or watch the information about the new snapshots.

I assume this change was made so that there will be no functional disparity between people who play with toggle sneak on and off. Toggle sneak was designed to be an accessibility setting, so it is a fair reason to want to make a change. Admittedly, this change does almost nothing to effect 90% of players, though for a small subset of people it will become one of the hardest nerfs to our playstyle in the game's entire history.

I can not express enough how crucial it has become for many of us in the trapping community that we are able to perform activities such as crafting, opening chests, and writing signs or in chat all without revealing our nametag to enemy players roaming the surface. It may be true that an invisibility potion will fully counteract this change, though in a UHC / battle royale type scenario, the time restraints commonly involved will render it almost impossible for players who wish to build a trap secretly to do so.

To restore parity between these two options without the involved negative impact to the trapping community in the latest snapshot's change, I suggest my own potential solution. A secondary sneaking keybind can be introduced. Players will have their original keybind set to regular, non-toggle sneak, and the new keybind will allow the player to toggle sneak. This will allow players who do not use toggle sneak to have the option to open their inventory / interact with other GUI while sneaking, and players who do use toggle sneak to remain unaffected.

Mojang‚Äôs recent decision to change the behavior of toggle sneak so that players no longer remain sneaked when opening their inventory is a step backwards in both gameplay flow and accessibility, and it absolutely deserves to be reverted. Previously, when players activated sneak toggle, they could confidently rely on their character to remain crouched regardless of opening the inventory, which was essential for survival situations, stealth mechanics, building on edges, and accessibility for players who rely on toggle rather than hold controls. This consistency made Minecraft smoother, because sneaking is not just a cosmetic action, it directly impacts safety by preventing accidental falls, hiding name tags during PvP, and maintaining immersion when building high structures or working near lava. By removing this, Mojang has unintentionally broken muscle memory developed over years and created unnecessary frustration, especially for disabled players who cannot hold down keys and depended on toggle being trustworthy. Imagine carefully crouching on a skyblock edge, opening your chest to grab blocks, and suddenly finding yourself unsneaked and one misclick away from death‚Äîthis is not fun design, this is unfair punishment for a problem that never existed. The community never demanded this change, and calling it a ‚Äúfix‚Äù ignores the fact that the old behavior was actually the correct one for accessibility and game logic. Mojang has always championed player choice

I didn't know this was going to be a change in the newest snapshot. The multiplayer server I play on updated to 1.21.10 and it has a massive inpact.

There are 10s of thousands of Minecraft players who play on multiplayer servers known as semi-anarchy. It's a server that has no rules within the normal minecraft gameplay, only rule is players are not allowed to hack or use clients, and most of these servers try to maintain as vanilla of a server environment as possible. 

This change completely upends one of the most important aspects of this gameplay and style, in that toggle crouch and staying crouched keeps you hidden from other players. Both while afk at farms and while sneaking around spawn, where players are constantly monitoring for a player to stop crouching and a nametag to show. 

There is no obvious benefit to the update. There is a SIGNIFICANT benefit to leaving that feature the way it was. How is it that with something this unique and thousands of players signing a petition Mojang has done nothing...

By implementing global bans, not just on java but bedrock too Microsoft (and by extension Mojang) is breaching player trust. Imagine this, you're hosting a server for you and your friends and you're playing on a popular server. A chat message of yours gets taken out of context and you receive a global ban, no you cant play on the server YOU host. Also consider anarchy servers where there are no rules and (for the most part) no bans. Anarchy servers will be mass report everyone with the use of hacked clients, no system you build will be able to handle that, no amount of people can verify all those reports are legit. Server moderation has always been left to the server owners, admins, and moderators. By being able to ban people from all servers, they are taking away control from the players. How long until Mojang under orders of Microsoft won't release server jars anymore? How long until private servers are abolished and you can only play on either realms or Microsoft approved servers? Will server owners have to pay a fee to Mojang/Microsoft to host their servers? Global bans are just one of the stepping stones to the downfall of Minecraft. There's and old saying among tradesmen, "If it ain't broke don't fix it." Global bans are Microsoft fixing something that was never an issue to begin with.

Please don't add this feature Mojang.  Coming from a Minecraft player since 2012, this chat reporting feature will be the brain death of a core part of Java.  Please listen to the united pleas from every corner of the Java community.  It isn't just the pvper community, or builder, redstoner, or anarchy community individually, its every single Java player from all walks of life, standing unified in one goal to ask you not to implement this new feature.  Stand by your words that life for Java edition players wouldn't change when we migrated our accounts, and please follow through on your agreement to listen to us as a faithful community.

I verily believe that chat reporting directly to Mojang Studios has no place in Minecraft because a feature like this can be easily exploited. For example, certain categories belong to servers with older players, other are very context-sensitive. Considering the amount of reports for the moderation team to filter, I highly doubt it will be possible to take the necessary details into account. It is especially worrying since false positives will result in bans to avoid false negatives, from what I understand. The fact that taking away control from server moderators is going to make the overall player experience worse is clear: we already have examples like shadow muting on servers and a terrible track record of a global ban system on Bedrock edition. This feature will either ruin multiplayer or be bypassed by server plugins. A lot of players bought licenses instead of resorting to pirating specifically to have access to multiplayer, so if Microsoft intends to keep Minecraft alive and running, I recommend they trust the community to moderate itself.

The solution is simple:

1. Make chat reporting a toggleable feature.
2. Add a parental control switch: To block children from playing on servers with chat reporting disabled.

The result:

* Parents don't need to worry.
* The diverse self-moderated Minecraft communities can continue to thrive.
* Big servers who want to attract as many young players as possible, will want to enable chat reporting. Or they'll host a separate server for underage players.

If chat reporting is not toggleable, server admins will find workarounds and it will spin completely out of Mojang's control.

Normally, a chat reporting system works in an online game. However, Minecraft (Java Edition) is not the game for it as it is very community-maintained. Players have already created custom ways to ban other players who break rules.

In Minecraft Bedrock Edition, This system is flawed but works a lot better (there being only 8 or so LINKED servers) 

In brief summary, Mojang. Don't add this.

I mostly hate the idea of chat reporting because of how many people will get false banned. Its not even a question of if people will, but how many. The chat moderators are regular people, and they would have to deal with thousands of reports per day. No matter how good they are, if you have to sit at your desk and look through hundreds of reports every hour(a lot of which would probably be spam or little children), do you think that you won't make a single mistake? These changes should happen to chat, skin and name reporting, and abuse of the report system:

  • If a player abuses the report system, they will be simply unable to report people rather than being banned. In severe cases, the player will be at most unable to report permanently rather than a ban from all realms and servers.
  • If a player gets chat reported, they will be simply muted on all servers and realms rather than being banned. In severe cases, the player will be at most permanently muted on servers and realms rather than a ban from all realms and servers.
  • If a player gets skin reported, then their skin will be changed to one of the default skins rather than being banned as normal. In severe cases, the player will be at most unable to change their skin and they are locked with any of the default skins rather than a ban from all realms and servers.
  • If a player gets name reported, they simply need a new name to play multiplayer and use realms and servers rather than being banned. In severe cases, the player will be at most unable to change their name permanently and be assigned a name like this: "Player", followed by a random digit number which is allowed to break the normal player name character limit rather than a ban from all realms and servers.

I truly see how the Minecraft team is trying to do a good thing with this new feature. However, the way it is being implemented brings up some serious concerns. Many of these servers are whitelisted so that only those we know are allowed onto these servers. In these servers, we may talk about adult topics or use adult language because we are all old enough and comfortable with it. I think it would be best if private servers had the opportunity to opt out of the chat reporting and ban system. That way, servers that want to keep Mojang's level of moderation will be able to easily, and servers that want to do the moderating themselves can do so as well.

To address any concern about player safety with an opt-out feature, servers that have opted out should have a warning screen when joining, stating that the server the player is about to join has opted out of the chat-moderation program, and may contain content not suitable for everyone. These features would bring the best of both worlds when it comes to player safety and good player experience.

Speaking as someone who purchased Minecraft back in its Beta development years; Chat Report should be entirely removed as it stands. This game has gone approximately a decade with a thriving multiplayer community (even under Minecraft's so-called "Dark Ages") who have been able to moderate themselves according to their rules, on servers they pay to host, oftentimes with their own tools to automate it relative to their needs.

By blanketing communities with chat reports that bypass their established rules and punishments, you are not only ignoring and taking away control from those communities looking to regulate themselves while having fun, but you are also smothering, driving away, and potentially destroying a lot of those communities (some that have been running for years with no troubles) in your crusade to centralize moderation. No amount of changing around vague rulings in the report will fix this inherent problem with the feature.

If you absolutely must keep chat report in some capacity, stick it as a Realms and officially hosted Mojang/Microsoft servers exclusive function. Those are your own servers, so it's your right to take away the ball in your court if players misbehave. But believe me, if this feature even so far as extends outside that scope, it will be thoroughly abused to the point that a lot of false-positives and context-ignorant reports and bans will be made. I would sooner trust a server's moderation team to make the right call over this report system.

Because this decision was made by Microsoft, not the devs (we assume, it would be even more of a PR disaster if it turned out Mojang staff made this decision), it probably won't get reverted. However, here is how to make it better:

1. Remove the defamation/impersonation rule. It requires stupidity on the level of not being able to use a computer to believe that a random Minecrafter is some person they claim to be

2. Be extremely, extremely careful with the imminent harm categories and the harassment and bullying categories. These are most likely to be abused/taken out of context. As an example, someone could say "I'm going to kill you" or "Your dead" in reference to PVP, or, in the case of the harassment and bullying category, somebody who joined an anarchy/factions server could report harassment through threats to grief their base, even though that is kind of the point of the server/game.

3. Allow some way to disable the feature for servers. If not directly in the config, maybe allow it in some way to server owners that can prove that their server has effective moderation.

4. Be very, very, very careful about bans. Especially perma-bans. Compared to other games known for banning people willy-nilly (Roblox), users have paid more than $25 for this game. Just mis-banning someone, even if they can appeal will really rub people the wrong way.

5. Keep to the specific predefined reasons for enforcement action, and if they change, update the community.

My thoughts regarding chat reporting. When I think about it, I can't imagine where chat reporting would fit in and solve anything. Realms are hosted by Microsoft, great, but realms are invite only, and you can choose to remove people who cause problems. Third party servers are NOT hosted by Microsoft and Microsoft should have NO business determining who is allowed to play on said third party servers nor what is allowed in said servers; third party servers are either small enough that the server owner can block/ban people that they don't want on their server, or are large enough to have a team of administrators and moderators that will do that work.

Chat reporting can be a major problem because server owners determine what is allowed on the server that they host, if someone else finds the IP and decides they don't like adults discussing adult things on a primarily adult server, players on said server can be banned from ALL online play, completely out of the hands of the server they were on.

And what will happen when there aren't enough employees to moderate reported chats? A bot is used and limits the chances or likelihood for any appeals? Even more reasons why global bans are a really bad idea (2/2):

-The "in game" problem: The fact is, this game includes lethal weapons, poison, fire and explosives. There are thousands of servers that feature some form of group player versus player combat or long term "war" (such as most factions servers). Considering the nature of such (again, privately owned) servers, many of them would deem in-game "threats" acceptable. Examples would be "threats" to blow up one's house, or to kill their character or group of Minecraft characters. These messages can and will be reported as harassment or terrorism, resulting in unnecessary bans.

- Report abusing, report spamming, bots: I would argue that it is quite obvious that people will attempt to abuse the feature. While mild cases will consist of players just reporting other players that they do not like, the problems comes when people use bots, multiple accounts or just a lot of time to flood the report system, in order to disrupt it or get people banned

-Scalability: considering the scale of the game, manual reviews are prone to become impractical, which could lead to automated bans

-Existence of better solutions: as the problem being tackled is player safety, it could be improved by instead adding more parental control features, servers opting in for such a feature, making a "friends only" chat feature or even having servers signal whether they are a safe, family-friendly environment

The reporting system as is cannot be implemented.  I would opt for no reporting system at all since chat should be kept private across all servers. BUT, if adding options really is the only way to do this, there's 2 to consider:

  1. Opting out of having reports for messages sent on your server.  Some servers are composed of adults and this is an obvious solution to prevent people abusing an agreed upon set of rules to get an entire server banned.
  2. Opting out of banning players with previous offenses from joining your server.  If a friend *has* joined a server with this invasive and flawed system in place, it should have no impact on if I can allow them into my own game with more lax rules.

The problems with false bans based on a pre-conceived agreement allowing inappropriate language would still be a huge concern if the feature is enabled by default, as it's possible for server operators will not be aware of the option's existence.  I would recommend having the report feature disabled by default, and server owners who want it can enable it.  Even then, I would never want to play on a server with it enabled and possibly lose ALL online minecraft access because of a false or maliciously-placed report.

As a side note, what jurisdiction will be used to determine if something is illegal, especially when servers can be international?

I got caught up in the worry at first, but given these facts I'm very reassured that this will make multiplayer a lot more friendly and safe; even just as a deterrent.

There's not enough context for a Mojang employee to get a clear and accurate picture of the situation. If I'm insulting my friend in a joking way and he's reciprocating, another person on the server could report it and we could end up banned. The case-reader has no context for the situation and would thus see it as an acceptable reason to ban. This has been seen many times on Bedrock with many cases of false bans. 

There's also the matter of how these logs are kept. On a server like Hypixel where you need to use /shout to talk to other teams will this be effective? I assume Hypixel uses a tellraw rather than an actual chat message, so could someone bypass the chat filter using commands? There's also the /me command on many servers. I've got a couple questions:

Why? This update simply isn't necessary for the greater multiplayer scene. Server owners (and their subsequent moderating teams) have been able to effectively moderate servers without intervention from outside sources. The new change would make sense if it were applied only to realms, where the servers are hosted and owned my Microsoft rather than 3rd parties (which should be allowed to pick their own rules on their servers that they pay for).

What? What has caused the apparent 'need' for this update to be implemented. The community of java players have not had a problem with the older format of punsihment.

How? How and why does the actions on one server (which may even allow some of the things that you could get reported for on their server, within legality) allow you to get banned from the entirety of multiplayer and realms? For example you could use a profanity on a server which formally allows it, and then a troll false reports you for said actions and then you are banned for no reason?

However, I concede that there are positive elements to this update such as the introduction of a TOGGLEABLE profanity filter (please keep it Toggleable) and the other report options seem to be more reasonable and inline with what you would expect.

Regardless, I see this update as a negative to the java experience besides its [few and far between] upsides, and should have the changes written in the comment and surrounding comments acted upon.

Thank you.

Speaking as someone who purchased Minecraft back in its Beta development years; Chat Report should be entirely removed as it stands. This game has gone approximately a decade with a thriving multiplayer community (even under Minecraft's so-called "Dark Ages") who have been able to moderate themselves according to their rules, on servers they pay to host, oftentimes with their own tools to automate it relative to their needs.

By blanketing communities with chat reports that bypass their established rules and punishments, you are not only ignoring and taking away control from those communities looking to regulate themselves while having fun, but you are also smothering, driving away, and potentially destroying a lot of those communities (some that have been running for years with no troubles) in your crusade to centralize moderation. No amount of changing around vague rulings in the report will fix this inherent problem with the feature.

If you absolutely must keep chat report in some capacity, stick it as a Realms and officially hosted Mojang/Microsoft servers exclusive function. Those are your own servers, so it's your right to take away the ball in your court if players misbehave. But believe me, if this feature even so far as extends outside that scope, it will be thoroughly abused to the point that a lot of false-positives and context-ignorant reports and bans will be made. I would sooner trust a server's moderation team to make the right call over this report system.

The whole entire system should be entirely removed. Allowing human mods to determine what's right, even if they have tons of experience, will lead to mistakes. There are a ton of loopholes to this, and can be easily weaponized to target innocent players. There are some major points of concern:

1. Issues with human moderation. Servers for the entirety of Minecraft's lifespan in Java edition have been able to moderate there own servers. There are mods and plugins that help with that, and each server should be able to moderate their own. When u now have someone else moderating, things can be taken out of context, and players can be given false bans. As a server owner, I should get to determine on what counts as a rule or not. Not the mod team

2. Exploitation and abuse. This whole entire system is completely flawed. A mod from the mod team can give out false bans for something that they don't like. I don't trust some random "experienced" mod to deal with moderating my server. Just like u don't trust random people with your banking info or other sensitive information. This leads to a lack of control, which will cause a mass exodus of players.

If this whole system is not taken down, or is made optional or restricted to only realms, then the community that the game developed over the last decade will leave.

The chat moderation feature is a terrible idea, as it is incredibly vulnerable to abuse by bad actors. It enables a high number of false bans, made even worse by the non-transparent appeal system. While you claim that every report will be evaluated by "highly trained" moderators, the amount of reports that can be expected will likely overwhelm even the best trained moderators, meaning they do not have the time to accurately asses each report. A larger Problem is the lack of context. Messages that can be highly offensive in public servers can be harmless or funny on private servers. Not every Minecraft player is a child and thus the general population should not be treated as such, especially on private servers, where all participants are usually aware of the server climate. Chat moderation or lack thereof on third-party servers should be left up to the respective admins, not a Mojang/Microsoft. You must be aware that this feature has the potential to kill communities, if not by the shear banning of the members, by the death of chat due the fear of a false ban. Third party hosted servers shouldn't be forced to deal with interference in how they moderate their space, if not removed, we should be allowed to opt out of this feature on our servers. Admins like myself, are all that third party servers need, real people part of the unique server's community. Not only is this a huge overstep, and blatant disregard for the communities we have built, by forcing us to work with an unwelcome system. It takes away the choices of Server Owners on how to run their servers, their private servers.

This is understandable with Realms, that is a space hosted specifically by Microsoft and Mojang. Privately hosted servers on third party sites should only be subject to the rules put in place by the hosting site, and the rules of the Server Owner. No one else, certainly not a system un-specialized for individual server needs.

Minecraft is not like Xbox Live, a universal ban will not work here because each server is its own environment. A blanket law will only result in unjust bans, and the destruction of communities.

Minecraft servers have been run by the community since their very creation, by a member of the community. To step in now after we have been self governing for over a decade, is not only an unwelcome change, but an invasive one that stands to be abused. We do not need your micromanaging, nor do we want it, keep your moderation to servers that Microsoft/Mojang hosts, and away from player run servers.
